statement.text: Critical Limb-Threatening Ischemia (CLTI), formerly Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI), is the most severe manifestation of peripheral arterial disease, characterized by chronic ischemic rest pain, ulceration, or gangrene attributable to arterial occlusive disease. Without revascularization, 25% will require major amputation within 1 year and 20-25% will die from cardiovascular events.
statement.formal: CLTI Definition: Chronic (>2 weeks) ischemia with rest pain OR tissue loss (ulcer/gangrene) + hemodynamic evidence (ABI <0.4, ankle pressure <50 mmHg, or toe pressure <30 mmHg) | Without revascularization: 25% major amputation, 20-25% mortality at 1 year

explanation.intuition: CLTI is when the blood supply to the leg is so poor that it can't even meet the basic needs at rest - the leg starts hurting without any exercise (rest pain), or the tissues start dying (ulcers, gangrene) because there's simply not enough blood to keep them alive. This is a 'leg heart attack' - the same process that blocks heart arteries is now threatening the leg. Without opening up the blood flow, the leg will be lost.
explanation.key_insight: CLTI is not just a leg problem - it's a marker of advanced systemic atherosclerosis. These patients have the highest cardiovascular mortality risk of any PAD subgroup. Treatment must address both limb salvage AND aggressive cardiovascular risk modification. Many CLTI patients die of heart attacks, not from their leg disease.
explanation.technical_details: The 2019 Global Vascular Guidelines introduced CLTI and the WIfI classification (Wound, Ischemia, foot Infection) to replace CLI, emphasizing that tissue loss severity, degree of ischemia, and infection status all contribute to amputation risk. WIfI stages limb threat from 1 (very low) to 4 (very high). Hemodynamic criteria for CLTI: ABI <0.4, ankle pressure <50-70 mmHg, toe pressure <30-50 mmHg, TcPO2 <30 mmHg. Revascularization options include endovascular (angioplasty, stent, atherectomy) or surgical bypass, guided by anatomy and GLASS staging.
common_misconceptions: CLTI can be treated with pills - revascularization is required for limb salvage
Amputation is inevitable - 70-80% of limbs can be salvaged with revascularization
Claudication will always progress to CLTI - only 15-20% of claudicants progress
CLTI is a local leg problem - it's a systemic atherosclerotic emergency

definitions_glossary.rest_pain: Ischemic pain at rest, typically in forefoot, worse at night, relieved by dependency
definitions_glossary.gangrene: Tissue necrosis due to inadequate blood supply
definitions_glossary.wif_i_classification: Wound, Ischemia, foot Infection staging system for CLTI
definitions_glossary.limb_salvage: Preservation of functional limb, avoiding major amputation
definitions_glossary.major_amputation: Amputation above the ankle (below-knee or above-knee)
definitions_glossary.minor_amputation: Amputation at or below the ankle (toe, ray, transmetatarsal)

clinical: Ischemic rest pain for >2 weeks requiring analgesia
Ischemic ulceration or gangrene of foot/toes

rest_pain_characteristics: Worse at night (horizontal position reduces perfusion pressure)
Relieved by dependency (hanging leg over bed, sleeping in chair)

arterial_ulcers: Often on pressure points (heel, malleoli, toes)

gangrene_types.dry_gangrene: Mummified, black, demarcated, low infection risk
gangrene_types.wet_gangrene: Infected, spreading, edematous, requires urgent intervention

wound.2: Deeper ulcer or gangrene limited to digits
wound.3: Extensive ulcer or gangrene extending to forefoot/midfoot

definition.@value: Most severe form of PAD with rest pain, ulceration, or gangrene threatening limb viability

sources.citation: Conte MS, et al. Global Vascular Guidelines on the Management of Chronic Limb-Threatening Ischemia. J Vasc Surg. 2019;69(6S):3S-125S.

learning_objectives: Define CLTI and its diagnostic criteria
Recognize CLTI as a marker of systemic atherosclerosis
clinical_pearls: Rest pain at night relieved by dependency = classic CLTI presentation
These patients often sleep in a chair - ask about sleeping position
CLTI patients die of heart attacks more than from their leg disease
WIfI stages amputation risk from 1 (very low) to 4 (very high)

medicalCode.description: Atherosclerosis of native arteries of extremities with rest pain
